Dear Mr. Soliz-Quiroga:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
6/2/20. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For any repeat violations, include an assessment of why the previous
corrective action plan was ineffective.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. If you fail to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, as recommended in Special
Investigation 2020C0223043, a First Provisional license is being recommended.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
1 of 27 newly hired employee files reviewed did not have 3 references completed.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
1 of 33 employee files reviewed did not have a current evaluation.
R 400.4115 First aid; CPR.
A person certified within the preceding 36 months in first aid and
within the preceding 24 months in age-appropriate
cardiopulmonary resuscitation by the American Red Cross, the
American Heart Association, or an equivalent organization or
institution approved by the department shall be on duty at all
times when 1 or more children are present.
1

1 of 33 employee files reviewed did not have documentation that First Aid and CPR
training was completed.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
updated treatment plan for each resident at least once every 90-
calendar days following the initial treatment plan.
3 of 3 short term case files reviewed either had late or no Updated Service Plans
completed.
The reports provided to this consultant indicated the reports were on-time however
the facility reported that those dates were falsified by the previous program
manager. The program manager has since been terminated and the program is now
closed.
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(2) Resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the minor
child’s behavior, chronological and developmental age, size,
gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and done in a manner consistent with the resident’s treatment
plan.
1 of 8 restraint reports reviewed indicated the resident was restrained because she
was in another resident’s room. The report did not indicate that a restraint was
necessary.
R 400.4161 Seclusion rooms; policies and procedures.
An institution approved to use a seclusion room shall establish
and follow written policies and procedures specifying its use.
The policy shall include, at a minimum, all of the following
provisions:
(a) Seclusion shall be performed in a manner that is safe,
appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the minor
child’s behavior, chronological and developmental age, size,
gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma.
2

1 of 3 seclusion reports indicated the youth was placed in the seclusion room
because she was in another resident’s room. The report did not indicate that
seclusion was necessary.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was provided with technical assistance in the following area:
 Supervisors should be taken out of ratio in order to provide coaching and
supervision of staff.
3

 Extra staff should be scheduled on campus in order to help when there is a
crisis. This would allow better supervision of the residents when there is a
crisis on campus and staff are pulled away from the house they are assigned
to.
 A clinical supervisor or manager needs to be hired to provide clinical oversight
and supervision.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The facility has submitted eight acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
Special Investigation 2019C0103043 was initiated when it was reported that a
resident was hurt by a staff member. There was no indication that the staff harmed
the resident. However, a restraint was done but the staff did not complete a Restraint
Report. The facility was found in violation of R 400.4159 Resident restraint and a
Corrective Action Plan (CAP) which appropriately addressed the violations was
accepted on 10/9/19.
Special Investigation 2019C0103051 was initiated when it was reported that staff
dragged a youth on the ground during a restraint. The facility was found in violation of
R 400.4159 Resident restraint and a CAP was accepted on 10/29/19.
Special Investigation 2019C0103055 was initiated when it was reported that a staff
member picked up a youth and transported him outside. The facility was found in
violation of R 400.4159 Resident restraint and a CAP was accepted on 12/3/19.
Special Investigation 2020C0103007 was initiated when it was reported that a staff
member put her hands around a youth’s neck while the youth was in a restraint. The
facility was found in violation of R 400.4159 Resident restraint with a CAP accepted
on 1/13/20.
Special Investigation 2020C0103010 was initiated when it was reported that a staff
member pushed a child in the chest and caused a bruise. It was found that the staff
did not intentionally harm the youth. The facility was found in violation of R 400.4150
Incident reporting due to staff not reporting the youth’s runaway to the consultant. A
CAP was accepted on 3/17/20.
4

Special Investigation 2020C0103012 was initiated when it was reported that three
residents were not allowed to return to the house after being AWOL during a winter
storm. The facility was found in violation of R 400.4158 Discipline for denial of shelter
and R 400.4109 Program statement for not following the facility’s runaway policy and
Youth Development Specialist expectations. A CAP was accepted on 4/13/20.
Special Investigation 2020C0223021 was initiated when it was reported that a staff
utilized an unapproved hold. The facility was found in violation of R 400.4159
Resident restraint for the improper hold and for not completing a restraint report. A
CAP was accepted on 4/17/20.
Special Investigation 2020C0223022 was initiated when it was reported that residents
were able to gain access to the med cart. The facility was found in violation of R
400.4126 Sufficiency of staff for not having enough staff to deal with the behaviors of
the youth and R 400.4142 Health services for not having the medication double
locked as indicated in their policy. A CAP was accepted on 4/28/20.
The facility has had many violations this review period and several of those violations
are repeat violations. Within this last year the facility has had three different Chief
Administrators and a significant amount of staff turnover. This, along with a delay in
staff hiring due to a lack of Human Resource staff, led to a shortage of well-trained
staff within the program. Despite the facility coming up with a plan to address the
staff issue there continues to be a shortage of not only management staff but also
extra staff on campus to help when a crisis arises. This lack of staffing has led to
significant safety issues on campus. The facility currently has a safety plan in place
which utilizes senior managers to provide support to the houses during times of need.
This safety plan however is only a temporary fix as more supervisors and/or
managers need to be in each house to provide the support needed. Additionally, the
staff and management turnover has led to newer staff being inadequately trained to
deal with the behaviors of the youth served by the facility. A plan was put into place
that would have the facility trainer providing in the moment coaching to the staff in the
houses. Having additional supervisors or managers in the houses will also help with
training new staff.
Around the time this inspection was completed the short-term assessment program
(STEP) contract was being closed. At the time of this report that program has been
closed and the house is no longer in use. After the inspection findings were provided
to the facility management team it was reported that the reports from STEP received
for the inspection were inaccurately dated. It was reported that the program manager
had falsified the date of the reports, but their report tracking system indicated those
reports were late. The management team provided the actual dates of the reports and
stated that the program manager for STEP was terminated in part due to this issue.
5

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility be issued a first
provisional license, as recommended in Special Investigation 2020C0223043.
